candidateProvision.title: Effect of Listing
candidateProvision.applicationToScenario: This provision directly applies to the scenario because two potential suppliers appear on a list of contractors proposed for debarment due to alleged fraudulent practices. According to FAR 9.405, contractors proposed for debarment are excluded from receiving contracts, and agencies shall not solicit offers from or award contracts to these suppliers unless there is a compelling reason determined by the agency head.

matchedKeyProvision.title: Effect of Listing
matchedKeyProvision.applicationToScenario: Two potential suppliers are proposed for debarment. This provision prohibits soliciting offers from or awarding contracts to debarred, suspended, or proposed for debarment contractors unless there's a compelling reason determined by the agency head. These suppliers must be excluded from consideration in the office equipment purchase.

candidateProvision.title: Total Small Business Set-Asides
candidateProvision.applicationToScenario: With an estimated value of $145,000, this procurement exceeds the micro-purchase threshold but is below the simplified acquisition threshold. Given that market research indicates at least five small businesses can provide the equipment at competitive prices, this procurement should be set aside exclusively for small businesses. This addresses the agency's previous citation for non-compliance with small business utilization requirements.

matchedKeyProvision.title: Total Small Business Set-Asides
matchedKeyProvision.applicationToScenario: With an estimated value of $145,000, this procurement exceeds the micro-purchase threshold but is below the simplified acquisition threshold. Since market research indicates at least five capable small businesses, this procurement must be set aside exclusively for small businesses, especially given the agency's previous non-compliance with small business utilization requirements.

candidateProvision.title: Sustainable Acquisition Policy
candidateProvision.applicationToScenario: This provision applies because the agency has a sustainability initiative requiring consideration of energy efficiency and environmental impact. FAR 23.103 mandates that 95% of new contract actions require products to be energy-efficient. The scenario specifically notes that computers and printers should be ENERGY STAR certified, which aligns with the ENERGY STAR designation requirement in this FAR provision.

matchedKeyProvision.title: Sustainable Acquisition Policy
matchedKeyProvision.applicationToScenario: The agency's sustainability initiative aligns with this provision requiring federal agencies to advance sustainable acquisition. The computers and printers must be ENERGY STAR certified, meeting the requirement that products be energy-efficient. This provision mandates that 95% of new contract actions require products with specific environmental attributes.

candidateIssue.issueDescription: The Purchasing Manager has an undisclosed conflict of interest with a key supplier owned by his brother-in-law and personally handles all negotiations with this supplier.
candidateIssue.correctiveAction: Implement a formal conflict of interest policy requiring all employees to disclose family or financial relationships with suppliers. Remove the Purchasing Manager from negotiations with the brother-in-law's company and assign an independent team to evaluate this supplier relationship. Conduct an audit of past transactions with this supplier to ensure pricing and terms were competitive and appropriate.

matchedKeyIssue.issueDescription: Undisclosed conflict of interest with the Purchasing Manager's brother-in-law owning a key supplier and personally handling negotiations.
matchedKeyIssue.correctiveAction: Develop and implement a formal conflict of interest policy requiring disclosure of all personal relationships with suppliers. Reassign the Purchasing Manager's responsibilities for this supplier to another employee. Conduct an independent audit of past transactions with this supplier to ensure fair pricing and terms. Provide ethics training to all purchasing staff.

candidateIssue.issueDescription: MedTech lacks formal supplier qualification processes and does not verify required certifications, licenses, or check suppliers against government exclusion lists.
candidateIssue.correctiveAction: Establish a documented supplier qualification procedure that includes verification of certifications, licenses, and compliance with quality standards. Implement a system to regularly check suppliers against government exclusion lists. Create a supplier audit program to verify compliance with requirements. Develop a supplier rating system based on quality, delivery, and compliance metrics.

candidateIssue.issueDescription: Purchase orders lack detailed specifications, quality requirements are communicated verbally, and changes are made without updating documentation. Records are only kept for one year.
candidateIssue.correctiveAction: Revise purchase order templates to include detailed specifications and quality requirements. Implement a formal change control process requiring written documentation of all purchase order changes. Extend record retention to at least five years or the lifetime of the device. Provide training to all purchasing staff on proper documentation practices and regulatory requirements.

candidateScenario.correctAction: Do not proceed with this supplier until proper verification of compliance is obtained. Request on-site audit or third-party verification of the supplier's certifications. Contact the certification body directly to verify the supplier's status. Consider alternative suppliers with verified certifications even if at higher cost. If timeline is critical, split the order between verified suppliers while continuing due diligence.

keyScenario.correctAction: Do not proceed with this supplier until proper verification of certifications is completed. Request on-site audit or third-party certification verification. Implement a formal supplier qualification process that includes verification of all certifications through official databases. Consider alternative suppliers with verified certifications even if costs are higher to ensure regulatory compliance.

applicableRegulations: OECD Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains
candidateScenario.correctAction: Require the supplier to complete the Conflict Minerals Reporting Template (CMRT) with full supply chain documentation. Verify the supplier conducts appropriate due diligence on their sources. Implement a contract clause requiring ongoing compliance and documentation. Consider third-party verification of the supplier's conflict minerals program. Ensure your company's SEC filings accurately reflect the current state of due diligence.

keyScenario.correctAction: Delay purchase until supplier provides detailed documentation of their supply chain. Request a Conflict Minerals Reporting Template (CMRT) from the supplier. Implement a conflict minerals due diligence program that includes supplier verification. Consider engaging a third-party auditor to verify supplier claims. Ensure compliance with SEC reporting requirements for conflict minerals.

candidateScenario.correctAction: Request updated Safety Data Sheets that comply with current GHS format requirements. Do not purchase materials until compliant documentation is received. Verify the supplier's TSCA compliance status through EPA's Chemical Data Reporting database. Consider alternative suppliers who maintain current documentation. Implement a procedure to verify SDS currency and compliance before all hazardous material purchases.

keyScenario.correctAction: Do not purchase materials with outdated SDS. Request current GHS-compliant SDS from the supplier. If supplier cannot provide updated documentation, seek alternative suppliers. Implement a procedure to verify SDS compliance before purchasing hazardous materials. Ensure all hazardous materials have current SDS documentation that meets GHS requirements.

applicableRegulations: FAR 52.219-8 Utilization of Small Business Concerns
candidateScenario.correctAction: Award the subcontract to the qualified small business to meet federal contract small business utilization requirements. Develop a transition plan to mitigate risks associated with the small business's limited experience. Provide additional oversight during initial work phases. Document the decision to support small business utilization in contract compliance reporting. Consider mentoring the small business to build capacity for future contracts.

keyScenario.correctAction: Award the subcontract to the qualified small business to meet federal contract small business subcontracting goals. Develop a mentor-protégé relationship between your company and the small business to address experience concerns. Document the selection process and small business utilization in your subcontracting plan. Provide appropriate support to ensure successful performance by the small business.
